tldr: Q3 2025 beat outlook with sales of $1.3B (+5%) and non-GAAP EPS of $3.88, led by retail, e-commerce, and RFID strength. Management guided Q4 sales growth of 8% to 11% with EPS of $4.20 to $4.40 and highlighted tariff mitigation progress and a $500M buyback.
bullets: Sales grew 5% to $1.3B with adjusted EBITDA margin of 21.6% and EPS up 11% to $3.88.
Asset Intelligence and Tracking grew 11% (RFID and printing led) while EVM grew 2% on strong mobile computing and softer scanning.
Q4 guide calls for 8% to 11% sales growth and EPS of $4.20 to $4.40; full-year EPS guided to about $15.80.
themes: Asset visibility and data capture adoption expanding
Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
Portfolio shifts and M&A reshaping focus

segments.title: Enterprise Visibility and Mobility (EVM)
points: Segment sales grew 2% with strong mobile computing and tougher compares in scanning.
Management sees longer-term upside from AI-enabled devices and wearables.

segments.title: Asset Intelligence and Tracking (AIT)
points: Segment sales grew 11% led by RFID and printing.
RFID adoption continues to expand across retail, e-commerce, and logistics workflows.

segments.title: Regional performance
points: North America grew 6% with strength in mobile computing and RFID; Canada was softer.
Asia Pacific grew 23% led by Australia, New Zealand, India, and Japan initiatives.
Latin America grew 8% on broad-based demand; EMEA declined 3% with weakness in Germany.

notes.title: Tariffs and pricing
points: Expected 2025 gross profit impact reduced to about $24M after mitigation.
Pricing actions expected to deliver about $60M annual benefit and roughly 1% sales growth.

notes.title: Capital allocation
points: Planned $500M share repurchases over the next 12 months.
Year-to-date buybacks exceeded $300M alongside Photoneo and Elo acquisitions.

themes.title: Demand and outlook
points: Q3 demand was solid with some orders pulled forward; Q4 guide assumes similar year-end spend to last year.
Management cited uneven demand in EMEA and Canada with manufacturing still soft.

themes.title: AI and refresh cycle
points: AI opportunity seen in next-gen handhelds and wearables, driving a multi-year refresh cycle.
Early pilots for AI Companion show productivity and sales conversion benefits.

top_questions.question: Why does Q4 guidance imply decelerating organic growth?
top_questions.summary: Management said H2 demand matches prior expectations with some Q3 pull-forward and tougher comps.

top_questions.question: How should investors think about 2026 demand and long-term targets?
top_questions.summary: Visibility is limited, but uneven demand persists while long-term growth drivers remain intact.

top_questions.question: How will the $500M buyback be deployed?
top_questions.summary: Plan is to execute steadily over four quarters with flexibility to use market volatility.

implications: RFID expansion and frontline AI pilots indicate continued attach opportunities beyond core hardware.
Elo integration expands the connected frontline TAM and should improve cross-sell into retail and hospitality.
competitive_notes: Pricing actions track broader industry moves in response to tariff impacts.
forecast_hooks: Monitor Q4 conversion of pipeline assumed in the guide and incremental margin performance.
Watch early benefits from Elo and Photoneo acquisitions on growth and EPS.

action_items: Track Q4 demand in EMEA and Canada for signs of stabilization.
Validate RFID growth drivers with retail and logistics channel checks.
open_questions: How quickly will AI Companion pilots convert into material software revenue?
What is the sustainable baseline for China exposure once supply chain changes mature?
watch_next_quarter: Early visibility into new segment reporting (Connected Frontline and Asset Visibility and Automation).
Update on tariff mitigation and pricing realization into 2026.
